newsitem.title: BANGLADESH: Southeast Bangladesh hit by new floods.
newsitem.headline: Southeast Bangladesh hit by new floods.

text.p: Heavy rains have flooded vast areas of southeastern Bangladesh, leaving some 50,000 people stranded in half-submerged homes, government officials said on Friday.
The deluge began on Thursday in the Cox's Bazar district as residents were still recovering from last month's floods which killed at least 100 people and made thousands homeless.
The road between Cox's Bazar town and the port of Chittagong was submerged in places and impassable.
There was no immediate word on damage to crops but officials said the impact would be limited if the waters receded within three or four days.
At least 10 people were missing after several fishing boats sank in the Bay of Bengal on Thursday evening, fishing community leaders in Cox's Bazar told reporters.
The rain also swept refugee camps where most of the 21,000 Burmese Moslems who fled into Bangladesh in 1992 to escape alleged military persecution continued a food boycott for a 12th day.
"The rain caused a temporary lull in the refugees' routine demonstration at the camp gates but they are safe inside," a police officer said.
The refugees, known as Rohingyas, started refusing food on July 21 in protest alleged attempts by Bangladesh to send them back to Burma by force.
